stem: The intensive care nurse is reviewing the EHR for two clients. Based on the documentation in the Chemistry & ABG panel, match the clinical set with the most likely acid-base impairment.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1: 22-year-old male with Type 1 Diabetes. Reports vomiting and abdominal pain. Breath has an acetone/fruity odor. Breathing is deep and rapid.
Patient 2: 45-year-old female following abdominal surgery. Received high-dose oxycodone. Currently snoring loudly; respiratory rate is 8/min and shallow.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient 1: BP 90/60, HR 124, RR 36 (Kussmaul).
Patient 2: BP 110/70, HR 62, RR 8, SpO2 88%.

rows.text: pH 7.22, PaCO2 30, HCO3 12 (Low pH, Low PaCO2, Low HCO3)
pH 7.25, PaCO2 68, HCO3 24 (Low pH, High PaCO2, Normal HCO3)
pH 7.50, PaCO2 42, HCO3 35 (High pH, Normal PaCO2, High HCO3)
pH 7.48, PaCO2 22, HCO3 23 (High pH, Low PaCO2, Normal HCO3)

rationale.correct: Low pH/Low PaCO2/Low HCO3 (r1) is Metabolic Acidosis (DKA findings in Patient 1). Low pH/High PaCO2/Normal HCO3 (r2) is Respiratory Acidosis (hypoventilation from narcotics in Patient 2). High pH/Normal PaCO2/High HCO3 (r3) indicates Metabolic Alkalosis (e.g., vomiting/suctioning). High pH/Low PaCO2/Normal HCO3 (r4) is Respiratory Alkalosis (hyperventilation/panic).
clinicalPearls: DKA always presents with Metabolic Acidosis. The Kussmaul breathing (RR 36) is the LUNGS trying to fix it by blowing off PaCO2.
K+ is often high in acidosis because H+ ions move into the cell and push K+ out.
Narcotic overdose is the classic cause of uncompensated Respiratory Acidosis.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that Patient 1's low PaCO2 means they have Respiratory Alkalosis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Check the pH first. If the pH is acidotic (7.22), then the primary problem is the one that causes acidosis (low HCO3). The low PaCO2 is just compensation.

mnemonic.title: ROME
mnemonic.expansion: R-Respiratory O-Opposite (pH up/PaCO2 down). M-Metabolic E-Equal (pH up/HCO3 up).
